transcription.text: So today I'm going to talk to you a little bit differently
than how Plasma is constructed or how you build Plasma.
But I want to actually talk about applications
that we're building and deploying into production
with Plasma and how Plasma is actually
going to scale games on the blockchain.
And I'm kind of a big fan of games
because I think it's actually what's
going to drive normal user adoption onto the blockchain.
So we're super passionate.
Even though we're researching Plasma,
we're always kind of passionate about how can we actually
get end users to play and use the blockchain, right?
Cool.
So this talk actually starts about 20 years ago.
So I used to play this game called Magic the Gathering.
Anybody here actually play Magic the Gathering or Yu-Gi-Oh?
All right.
There's a whole bunch of people in a nerdy crowd,
so it wasn't a big surprise.
So we used to like-- when we were in high school,
we used to play Magic the Gathering.
We used to play card games and Yu-Gi-Oh and all this stuff.
And we loved it, right?
And about a year ago, when we were starting a blockchain
company, we said, you know what?
It would be really amazing if we put Magic the Gathering
or Hearthstone on the blockchain, because you could
have real ownership of cards.
You could have provably correct logic.
You could actually prevent fraud.
You could actually have real money embedding inside the games.
We said, let's do it.
So I don't know if you guys were developing Ethereum
about a year ago, but having a full card game on the blockchain
was just not reasonable, right?
And that's where we've kind of taken this journey
over the last year about trying to take a very simple application
and actually scale it and run it on top of the blockchain.
So cool.
So you're looking at me.
You're like, Matt, I play Fortnite.
I play all these games.
Why do I need it on the blockchain?
That doesn't make any sense.
The blockchain is for transferring value.
It's for running prediction markets and stuff like this.
It's not for games.
So I actually think that games have some really amazing use
cases that actually blow away traditional games.
So obviously everybody talks about real ownership of assets,
like the items that you own in game,
you can really own them, you can trade them.
You know they're digital scarcity.
If you guys have ever played an online game,
like an MMO or any other kind of game,
you know that the publisher will just flood new items continually.
And if you had some valuable staff of magic,
it will like over time lose its value.
But it's kind of nice that we can actually
know what the value of our items are
because we actually know what the scarcity of our items.
What's also kind of cool is Vitalik actually had this quote
where like he was really sad when they changed
the rules of StarCraft and he stopped playing
because the one day they like changed how the game worked.
And I think what's kind of cool is if a game runs
on the blockchain, we could just literally fork it.
If we think that like we want to play
Ultima Online with Dreadlords or we want to play
the original World of Warcraft before they nerfed it,
we could just literally fork the blockchain
and be able to run our version of the game, right?
And then the last point, we just made this realization
very recently and I think that this is going to be
like one of the biggest features, is because we have
a trustable VM, because we have the EVM and it's trustable,
we could actually have end users upload code
into our game servers.
And now we could have anybody that plays our game
could make mods for the game and the mods are not cheatable.
They could actually be running on the chain
and other people could be introspecting the mods.
So we think that there's a ton of amazing use cases
for actually wanting to run these games on the blockchain.
And now you can actually monetize it.
So like you could actually build a game,
we could actually build like game modes
and actually be able to charge users for them.
So gaming on the blockchain has actually been around
for quite a long time.
So I don't know if you guys have ever seen Bitcoin
actually had the first blockchain games.
So about five years ago, there was this group called XCP
and they actually built blockchain games
but they had like custom miners
and then they would put little bits of metadata
on top of the Bitcoin chain.
So it was kind of the first start
and basically the only thing they had was asset ownership.
You could prove that you own some asset
and asset had scarcity.
And then Ethereum came out, right?
And obviously we all know last year
last year was when the big jump happened.
When CryptoKitties came out, everybody said,
"Oh my God, Ethereum actually runs a pretty cool application."
And these ERC721s came out
and everybody was jumping all over it, right?
But it was kind of boring, right?
So anybody here ever play CryptoKitties?
Okay, like half the audience.
It was kind of just a Ponzi scheme
with like a cute graphic scheme.
So don't get me wrong, I have a couple cats.
I'm a fan, but it was kind of like,
"Okay, this is cool, but like,
this isn't anything that like mainstream gamers
are gonna care about.
This isn't gonna come in.
I'm not gonna get my electronic gaming monthly
and see CryptoKitties in it, right?
It's kind of still a very boring game.
But it did invent the concept
of these non-fungible tokens, right?
So now we have like the first kind of building block
for all of this gaming technology, right?
And obviously we all know like proof of work chains,
like Bitcoin and Ethereum have been really secure.
And they've been, but the thing is,
is that they're still quite slow.
So we're never gonna actually be able to run
a full game on a proof of work chain.
At least, I don't think we will.
So I think what we're gonna see
is we're gonna see a combination
of other kind of consensus mechanisms
joined with Plasma.
And Plasma will be adding the security
from the proof of work chain.
And then you're gonna have side chains
that are running on DPOS or proof of stake,
or maybe other consensus algorithms as they come out.
So we're currently a really big fan of DPOS
because you can actually deploy applications today.
So if you look at a couple of popular chains,
like Steamit and EOS and then Loom and a few others,
they're all, a lot of them are kind of going
with this DPOS model.
And it's a lot more centralized
and it's good for applications
that have lower value like games.
I wouldn't wanna run my core blockchain on DPOS.
I wouldn't run and run like the blockchain
that holds all the value on a DPOS chain,
but you can be able to run pretty interesting
blockchain applications on top of DPOS.
So we're big fans of side chains.
So these guys earlier have been talking about Plasma
and using Plasma for payments
and that there are Plasma chains.
So there's kind of really three scaling techniques
right now that we're talking about with blockchain apps.
We have the state channels,
we have Plasma and side chains.
And I kind of think that it's gonna be a combination.
I don't think that you're gonna see
there's some groups that say,
oh, you can run everything on Plasma,
I don't believe that's true.
You can run everything on a side chain,
sure you could do that,
but then you don't have as much security.
So I think really combining the Plasma
with the side chains is actually what's going to be,
what's actually making these applications run.
So that was kind of a very, very long-winded way

it's a real card game that runs on a side chain.

oh, everybody has to put in a half an ETH

And the owner of the contract could actually monetize

and they would be able to extend the functionality

this is also gonna cause decentralization

So you say, Matt, this is a plasma talk

I said, yeah, so one of the issues we had

we had a bunch of people back the game
and we had like 2,000 users kind of donate to fund the game.

We would have probably eaten up every single transaction

on the entire chain if we were gonna do this.
So obviously it wasn't even feasible on day one
and this was only with 2 users, with 2,000 users, right?
So that's when we started to say,
and these are what the cards look like, by the way,
just so you have kind of a good reference.
So we were like, okay, how can we give them these assets,
and how can we secure them?
So first we wanna be able to issue assets on side chains.

you wanna on-ramp these users, right?
And maybe a few hours in, then you wanna tell them about crypto,
you wanna start with having them play these games,

oh, you mean I can move my assets to Ethereum?
You mean that I can sell my assets for Ether,

and they don't even really realize

But basically, the idea is that you have a proof of stake
network, whether it's DPOs, a proof of stake,
or in some cases, the proof of authority network,
that is allowing users to be able to do

there are other people that could actually
work on your behalf and actually penalize the side chain.
